awd_titl_txt: CIF: Medium:  Interference Alignment and the Rate-Reliability Tradeoff of Wireless Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Modern society is increasingly relying on wireless networks. Spectrum is the most valuable resource in a wireless network. How to share this limited resource among different users is one of the main challenges. When different users share the same spectrum, their signals cause interference to each other. Therefore, the most distinctive feature of wireless networks is the phenomenon of interference. In this research, we place special emphasis on practical considerations to ultimately find new ? realistic ? methods to deal with interference.

A recent development is the idea of interference alignment which has shown that the capacity of wireless networks may be significantly higher than previously believed. Since higher rates invariably come at the cost of lower reliability, the emerging capacity results present only half the picture. This research is motivated by the need to complete this picture by evaluating the benefits of interference alignment schemes on the performance of wireless networks when both rate and reliability are of concern. The research follows three main thrusts. First, we examine the rate-reliability tradeoff of interference alignment schemes from the traditional coding perspective which places emphasis on low decoding complexity, usually at the cost of a restricted notion of optimality. Second, we examine the rate-reliability tradeoff of interference alignment schemes in the Shannon framework which allows strong definitions of optimality, usually at the cost of unbounded delay and complexity. These two thrusts are the stepping stones to the final thrust to reconcile the findings from the two distinct perspectives and use the collective insights to develop new physical layer schemes that can operate at the frontier of the rate-reliability tradeoff.

por.por_cntn:
Modern society is increasingly relying on wireless communication networks. Spectrum is the most valuable resource in a wireless network. How to share this limited resource among different users is one of the main challenges. When different users share the same spectrum, their signals cause interference to each other. Therefore, the most distinctive feature of wireless networks is the phenomenon of interference.

This research was motivated by the need to evaluate the performance of wireless networks suffering from interference when both rate and reliability are of concern. The research followed three main thrusts. First, we examined  the rate-reliability tradeoff of interference schemes from the traditional coding perspective which places emphasis on low decoding complexity. Second, we characterized the degrees of freedom and generalized degrees of freedom of different interference alignment schemes. Third, we developed new physical layer schemes that can operate at highest multiplexing gain while providing a diversity more than one.

 

The project has settled a few open research problems in the literature and have proposed new physical layer schemes that provide properties that did not exist before. For example:

 

-        We have settled the oldest open conjecture on the collapse of degrees of freedom, also an inaugural Information Theory and Application (ITA) Workshop open problem, to show that the degree of freedom do collapse under finite precision channel knowledge at the transmitters.

-        We have designed the first low complexity differential schemes for multi-user multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) systems.

-        We have proposed new interference alignment methods that can maintain the maximum Degree of Freedom gain and improve the ergodic mutual information in the long-term regime, while for the first time, provide a diversity gain greater than one in the short-term regime.

-    We have discovered new ways in which dynamic phenomena such as channel coherence patterns, and alternating channel knowledge, whether naturally present or deliberately imposed upon the network, affect the available degrees of freedom per user.

 

The project has produced 18 journal papers and many conference papers and presentations.

We have disseminated our research results through these papers and by presenting them in  invited talks, keynote/plenary talks, and IEEE Communications Society Distinguished Lectures in different venues.

One of the project’s journal papers has received the 2015 IEEE Signal Processing Society Young Author Best Paper Award. Two of the project’s conference papers have received Best Paper Awards in IEEE Globecom 2012 and IEEE Globecom 2014. Another project’s conference paper was selected among the Best of Globecom'14.

We have advised many PhD students who have done their PhD dissertations on topics related to this project. The graduate students who worked on the project became familiar with cutting edge knowledge in the field.
